entries.title: The Proxy We Trusted Too Much
entries.summary: How a third-party CORS proxy became a single point of silent failure.
entries.content:
Once mock data was identified as the culprit, the obvious question followed: why was the app falling back in the first place?

The answer led straight to a dependency we barely thought about — a public CORS proxy.

Direct calls to the Internet Archive CDX API were blocked by browser CORS rules, so the app relied on AllOrigins to relay requests. For a long time, this worked well enough to fade into the background. Until it didn’t.

At the time of failure, AllOrigins was behaving inconsistently. Some requests timed out entirely. Others returned HTTP 200 with incomplete or invalid JSON. From the browser’s perspective, the request "succeeded."

The app believed it too.

Because the fetch resolved, success was logged immediately. Only afterward did JSON parsing fail — triggering a catch block that quietly returned mock data.

No error reached the UI. No warning appeared in the logs. The system degraded smoothly, invisibly, and convincingly.

This wasn’t a single bug. It was a chain of assumptions: that a proxy would be reliable, that HTTP 200 meant usable data, and that logging success early was harmless.

None of those assumptions held.

entries.title: Timeouts, Or Why Waiting Forever Is a Bug
entries.summary: The missing timeout that let failures masquerade as success.
entries.content:
One detail kept showing up in logs and traces: requests that never clearly failed.

The original CDX fetch logic had no timeout. If a proxy stalled, the browser would wait. If the proxy returned late with malformed data, the code would move on as if everything was fine.

This is where the fix finally became clear.

The solution wasn’t just switching proxies — it was enforcing boundaries. A request that takes too long isn’t slow; it’s failed.

AbortController was added with a hard timeout. If the CDX request didn’t respond in time, it was explicitly aborted. No partial success. No ambiguous state.

Only after receiving valid JSON would the app log success. Only after validation would results reach the UI.

This changed the behavior immediately. Instead of quiet degradation, failures became visible. Instead of fake certainty, the system admitted when it didn’t know.

It was a small change in code, but a large change in philosophy: uncertainty is better than lying.

entries.title: The Moment Real Data Came Back
entries.summary: What it looked like when the CDX API finally returned genuine archive data again.
entries.content:
After adding timeouts, validation, and proxy fallback, there was only one question left: did it actually work?

The answer came not from logs or tests, but from the data itself.

Search results jumped from a perfectly round 200 entries to over a thousand. Timestamps varied naturally. Charts lost their artificial symmetry.

This time, nothing looked neat — and that was the point.

The data finally had the irregularity of reality.

This wasn’t a triumphant moment with fireworks. It was quieter than that. A recognition that the system was no longer pretending.

For the first time since the issue began, Archive-OmniDash was showing what the Internet Archive actually contained — not what the app wished it did.

That confirmation mattered more than any automated checkmark. It came from observing behavior that could no longer be faked by mock data.

entries.title: What This Broke Changed Forever
entries.summary: How one quiet failure permanently changed how success is defined.
entries.content:
This incident didn’t just fix a CDX bug. It changed how success is measured.

From this point forward, logs stopped being trusted on their own. Screenshots stopped counting without OCR. Status indicators stopped existing without real verification behind them.

Green checkmarks became suspect. Passing tests became provisional. Anything that couldn’t be validated was treated as unknown, not assumed correct.

Perhaps the most important shift was cultural: failures were no longer something to smooth over. They were surfaced deliberately, even if that made the app feel less polished in the short term.

Because a system that admits failure is easier to fix than one that hides it.

Archive-OmniDash didn’t just recover from a broken API path. It learned to stop lying — to users, to tests, and to itself.

That lesson will outlast this particular bug.
